title: Kitten that was born tiny never grows bigger, worrying her owners, but turns out she just has dwarfism and will be tiny forever: 'We weren't sure that she would even make it'
description: Something that we learned very quickly after we adopted our first kitten is that… kittens grow up fast. One moments, your kitten can fit in the palm of your hand because it's so small. The next second, that same kitten is so big it barely fits in your lap when you sit down. Kittenhood passes quickly, so we have to cherish it. Take those pictures, hang them up, kiss that kitten's itty bitty forehead as many times as it will allow, because soon enough, it won't be a kitten anymore. Usually. Sometimes, a kitten is born with a condition that makes it stay small forever. Meet Mini, a kitty cat with dwarfism. This teeny weeny cat is never going to get any bigger than it already is. It is forever a kitten. Sort of. Obviously, she's going to keep growing up and getting smarter and more cunning, but her size will remain forever the same. Which makes everything so much harder. Everyone knows it's way more difficult to ignore the demands of a kitten. The smaller they are, the bigger their powers of meownipulation.
author: Mariel Ruvinsky
excerpt: Kitten that was born tiny never grows bigger, worrying her owners, but turns out she just has dwarfism and will be tiny forever: 'We weren't sure that she would even make it' - World's largest collection of cat memes and other animals
text: We always tell people to cherish the days that their cat will be small, because those days are few. Not here. And yes, a part of us is indeed jealous. We miss the days when our chonky cats could fit on our shoulder and walk around with us around the house like that.  But more than anything, we wish this kitty health. We know of a bunch of health risks that come along with a cat having dwarfism, and we hope - we pray - that this kitty will be healthy and happy with its family for many, many years to come.
html:
We always tell people to cherish the days that their cat will be small, because those days are few. Not here. And yes, a part of us is indeed jealous. We miss the days when our chonky cats could fit on our shoulder and walk around with us around the house like that. 

But more than anything, we wish this kitty health. We know of a bunch of health risks that come along with a cat having dwarfism, and we hope - we pray - that this kitty will be healthy and happy with its family for many, many years to come.
